Q1: A Deterministic Life Cycle Model with Savings

An agent lives for TTT periods, works in the first RRR periods of life and is rewarded with (a deterministic) income yty_tyt​ in each working period, retires at R+1R+1R+1 and has to live until the final period TTT from the savings accumulated throughout the working life. The agent thus solves the following maximization problem:{max{ct,at+1}t=1T∑t=1Tβtlog(ct)s.t.at+1=(1+r)(at+yt−ct),a0 given\left\{\begin{array}{lll} max_{\left\{c_t, a_{t+1}\right\}^T_{t=1}}\sum^T_{t=1}\beta^t log(c_t)\\\text{s.t.}\\ a_{t+1}=(1+r)(a_t+y_t-c_t), \qquad a_0 \enspace \text{ given}\end{array} \right.⎩⎨⎧​max{ct​,at+1​}t=1T​​∑t=1T​βtlog(ct​)s.t.at+1​=(1+r)(at​+yt​−ct​),a0​ given​where 0<β≤1,0<\beta\le1,\enspace0<β≤1, r≥1,r\ge1,\enspacer≥1, 0<β≤1,0<\beta\le1,\enspace0<β≤1, yt>0y_t>0yt​>0 for t≤R,t\le R,\enspacet≤R, yt=0y_t=0yt​=0 for t>R.t>R.t>R.

  1. What is (are) the state variable(s)?

Solution:

State variables are the ones that are known at the decision time, cannot be changed at that time and have an influence on your decision. The state variables in Q1 are: at,ta_t, \enspace tat​,t yty_tyt​ is not a state variable. yty_tyt​ is a deterministic process, which is already known before the decision time and hence already accounted for by the agent at the time of the decision. One could say e.g. that E(yt+1)=yt+1E(y_{t+1})=y_{t+1}E(yt+1​)=yt+1​.

ttt is a state variable in finite-horizon problems!

  1. What is (are) the control variable(s)?

Solution:

Control variables are the ones that are optimally chosen. The control variables in Q1 are: at+1,cta_{t+1}, c_tat+1​,ct​

Note: when stating the Bellman equation, solve the constraint for ctc_tct​ and substitute it in (see question 3).

  1. State this agent’s Bellman equation.

Solution:

v(state variables) = max_controlvariable= main function + \beta v_{t+1}(state variables at time t+1))

For the main function, solve the constraint for ctc_tct​ and plug it in:
at+1=(1+r)(at+yt−ct)(1+r)ct=(1+r)(at+yt)−at+1ct=at+yt−at+11+r\begin{aligned}a_{t+1}&=(1+r)(a_t+y_t-c_t)\\(1+r)c_t&=(1+r)(a_t+y_t)-a_{t+1}\\c_t&=a_t+y_t-\frac{a_{t+1}}{1+r}\end{aligned}at+1​(1+r)ct​ct​​=(1+r)(at​+yt​−ct​)=(1+r)(at​+yt​)−at+1​=at​+yt​−1+rat+1​​​

The Bellman equation reads:
vt(at)=max⁡at+1{log(at+yt−at+11+r)+βvt+1(at+1)}v_t(a_t)=\max_{a_{t+1}}\left\{log\left(a_t+y_t-\frac{a_{t+1}}{1+r}\right)+\beta v_{t+1}(a_{t+1})\right\}vt​(at​)=at+1​max​{log(at​+yt​−1+rat+1​​)+βvt+1​(at+1​)}
Note:

  • the Bellman equation depends on time ttt in finite horizon problems (slide 3.27)
    • write vtv_tvt​ in this case!!!
  1. Assume β=1\beta=1β=1 and r=0r=0r=0. Assume that the agent has no utility after he dies, vT+1=0v_{T+1}=0vT+1​=0 and aT+1≥0a_{T+1}\ge 0aT+1​≥0 (not possible to leave debt). Solve this maximization problem using the Bellman equation. This means you should derive the policy function for each period.

Solution:

Do backward induction.
1.1 Bellman equation in last period TTT is:
vT(aT)=max⁡aT+1≥0{log(aT+yT−aT+11+r)+βvT+1(aT+1)}v_T(a_T)=\max_{a_{T+1}\ge0}\left\{log\left(a_T+y_T-\frac{a_{T+1}}{1+r}\right)+\beta v_{T+1}(a_{T+1})\right\}vT​(aT​)=aT+1​≥0max​{log(aT​+yT​−1+raT+1​​)+βvT+1​(aT+1​)}
By the exercise, vT+1=0v_{T+1}=0vT+1​=0, β=1\beta=1β=1 (doesn’t matter anyway) and r=0r=0r=0:
vT(aT)=max⁡aT+1≥0{log(aT+yT−aT+1)}v_T(a_T)=\max_{a_{T+1}\ge0}\left\{log\left(a_T+y_T-a_{T+1}\right)\right\}vT​(aT​)=aT+1​≥0max​{log(aT​+yT​−aT+1​)}

1.2 Optimal policy for aT+1(aT)a_{T+1}(a_T)aT+1​(aT​):
“An optimal policy has the property that, whatever the initial state and decision are, the remaining decisions must constitute an optimal policy with regard to the state resulting from the first decision”

aT+1(aT)=0a_{T+1}(a_T)=0aT+1​(aT​)=0

1.3 Compute the value function of period TTT by plugging in the optimal policy:
vT(aT)=log(aT+yT)v_T(a_T)=log(a_T+y_T)vT​(aT​)=log(aT​+yT​)
2.1 Plug the computed value function into period T−1T-1T−1:
vT−1(aT−1)=max⁡aT{log(aT−1+yT−1−aT)+1∗vT(aT)}=max⁡aT{log(aT−1+yT−1−aT)+log(aT+yT)}\begin{aligned}v_{T-1}(a_{T-1})&=\max_{a_{T}}\left\{log\left(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-a_T\right)+1*v_T(a_T)\right\}\\&=\max_{a_{T}}\left\{log\left(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-a_T\right)+log(a_T+y_T)\right\}\end{aligned}vT−1​(aT−1​)​=aT​max​{log(aT−1​+yT−1​−aT​)+1∗vT​(aT​)}=aT​max​{log(aT−1​+yT−1​−aT​)+log(aT​+yT​)}​

2.2 Take the FOC and solve for aTa_TaT​ to get optimal policy:
∂∂aT=1aT−1+yT−1−aT∗(−1)+1aT+yT∗1=01aT+yT=1aT−1+yT−1−aTaT−1+yT−1−aT=aT+yT−2aT=yT−aT−1−yT−1aT=aT−1+yT−1−yT2\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial a_T}=\frac{1}{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-a_T}*(-1)+\frac{1}{a_T+y_T}*1&=0\\\frac{1}{a_T+y_T}&=\frac{1}{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-a_T}\\a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-a_T&=a_T+y_T\\-2a_T&=y_T-a_{T-1}-y_{T-1}\\[1em]a_T&=\frac{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-y_T}{2}\end{aligned}∂aT​∂​=aT−1​+yT−1​−aT​1​∗(−1)+aT​+yT​1​∗1aT​+yT​1​aT−1​+yT−1​−aT​−2aT​aT​​=0=aT−1​+yT−1​−aT​1​=aT​+yT​=yT​−aT−1​−yT−1​=2aT−1​+yT−1​−yT​​​

Optimal policy for aT(aT−1)a_T(a_{T-1})aT​(aT−1​): aT(aT−1)=aT−1+yT−1−yT2a_T(a_{T-1})=\frac{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-y_T}{2}aT​(aT−1​)=2aT−1​+yT−1​−yT​​

2.3 Compute the value function of period T−1T-1T−1 by plugging in the optimal policy:
vT−1(aT−1)=log(aT−1+yT−1−aT)+log(aT+yT)=log(aT−1+yT−1−aT−1+yT−1−yT2)+log(aT−1+yT−1−yT2+yT)=log(12(aT−1+yT−1+yT))+log(12(aT−1+yT−1+yT))=2∗log(12(aT−1+yT−1+yT))=2[log(aT−1+yT−1+yT)−log(2)]\begin{aligned}v_{T-1}(a_{T-1})&=log\left(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-a_T\right)+log(a_T+y_T)\\&=log\left(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-\frac{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-y_T}{2}\right)+log\left(\frac{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-y_T}{2}+y_T\right)\\&=log\left(\frac{1}{2}(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T)\right)+log\left(\frac{1}{2}(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T)\right)\\&=2*log\left(\frac{1}{2}(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T)\right)\\&=2\left[log(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T)-log(2)\right]\end{aligned}vT−1​(aT−1​)​=log(aT−1​+yT−1​−aT​)+log(aT​+yT​)=log(aT−1​+yT−1​−2aT−1​+yT−1​−yT​​)+log(2aT−1​+yT−1​−yT​​+yT​)=log(21​(aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​))+log(21​(aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​))=2∗log(21​(aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​))=2[log(aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​)−log(2)]​

since log(mn)=log(m)−log(n)log(\frac{m}{n})=log(m)-log(n)log(nm​)=log(m)−log(n).

3.1 Plug this computed value into period T−2T-2T−2:
vT−2(aT−2)=max⁡aT−1{log(aT−2+yT−2−aT−1)+1∗vT−1(aT−1)}=max⁡aT−1{log(aT−2+yT−2−aT−1)+2[log(aT−1+yT−1+yT)−log(2)]}\begin{aligned}v_{T-2}(a_{T-2})&=\max_{a_{T-1}}\left\{log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-a_{T-1})+1*v_{T-1}(a_{T-1})\right\}\\&=\max_{a_{T-1}}\left\{log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-a_{T-1})+2\left[log(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T)-log(2)\right]\right\}\end{aligned}vT−2​(aT−2​)​=aT−1​max​{log(aT−2​+yT−2​−aT−1​)+1∗vT−1​(aT−1​)}=aT−1​max​{log(aT−2​+yT−2​−aT−1​)+2[log(aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​)−log(2)]}​

3.2 Take the FOC and solve for aT−1a_{T-1}aT−1​ to get optimal policy:
∂∂aT−1=1aT−2+yT−2−aT−1(−1)+21aT−1+yT−1+yT∗1=021aT−1+yT−1+yT=1aT−2+yT−2−aT−12(aT−2+yT−2−aT−1)=aT−1+yT−1+yT−3aT−1=yT−1+yT−2aT−2−2yT−2aT−1=23(aT−2+yT−2)−13(yT−1+yT)\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial a_{T-1}}=\frac{1}{a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-a_{T-1}}(-1)+2\frac{1}{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T}*1&=0\\2\frac{1}{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T}&=\frac{1}{a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-a_{T-1}}\\2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-a_{T-1})&=a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T\\-3a_{T-1}&=y_{T-1}+y_T-2a_{T-2}-2y_{T-2}\\a_{T-1}&=\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2})-\frac{1}{3}(y_{T-1}+y_T)\end{aligned}∂aT−1​∂​=aT−2​+yT−2​−aT−1​1​(−1)+2aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​1​∗12aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​1​2(aT−2​+yT−2​−aT−1​)−3aT−1​aT−1​​=0=aT−2​+yT−2​−aT−1​1​=aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​=yT−1​+yT​−2aT−2​−2yT−2​=32​(aT−2​+yT−2​)−31​(yT−1​+yT​)​

Optimal policy for aT−1(aT−2)a_{T-1}(a_{T-2})aT−1​(aT−2​): aT−1(aT−2)=23(aT−2+yT−2)−13(yT−1+yT)a_{T-1}(a_{T-2})=\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2})-\frac{1}{3}(y_{T-1}+y_T)aT−1​(aT−2​)=32​(aT−2​+yT−2​)−31​(yT−1​+yT​)
3.3 Compute the value function at time T−2T-2T−2 by plugging in that optimal policy:
vT−2(aT−2)=max⁡aT−1{log(aT−2+yT−2−aT−1)+2[log(aT−1+yT−1+yT−log(2)]}=log(aT−2+yT−2−(23(aT−2+yT−2)−13(yT−1+yT)))+2[log((23(aT−2+yT−2)−13(yT−1+yT))+yT−1+yT)−log(2)]=log(13(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT))+2[log(23(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT))−log(2)]=log(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT)−log(3)+2[log(2(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT))−log(3)−log(2)]=log(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT)+2log(2(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT))−2log(3)−log(3)−2log(2)\begin{aligned}v_{T-2}(a_{T-2})&=\max_{a_{T-1}}\left\{log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-a_{T-1})+2\left[log(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}+y_T-log(2)\right]\right\}\\&=log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}-(\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2})-\frac{1}{3}(y_{T-1}+y_T)))+2\left[log\left(\left(\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2})-\frac{1}{3}(y_{T-1}+y_T)\right)+y_{T-1}+y_T\right)-log(2)\right]\\&=log(\frac{1}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T))+2\left[log(\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T))-log(2)\right]\\&=log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)-log(3)+2\left[log(2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T))-log(3)-log(2)\right]\\&=log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)+2log(2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T))-2log(3)-log(3)-2log(2)\end{aligned}vT−2​(aT−2​)​=aT−1​max​{log(aT−2​+yT−2​−aT−1​)+2[log(aT−1​+yT−1​+yT​−log(2)]}=log(aT−2​+yT−2​−(32​(aT−2​+yT−2​)−31​(yT−1​+yT​)))+2[log((32​(aT−2​+yT−2​)−31​(yT−1​+yT​))+yT−1​+yT​)−log(2)]=log(31​(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​))+2[log(32​(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​))−log(2)]=log(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)−log(3)+2[log(2(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​))−log(3)−log(2)]=log(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)+2log(2(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​))−2log(3)−log(3)−2log(2)​

4.1 Plug this computed value into period T−3T-3T−3
vT−3(aT−3)=max⁡aT−2{log(aT−3+yT−3−aT−2)+1∗vT−2(aT−2)}=max⁡aT−2{log(aT−3+yT−3−aT−2)+log(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT)+2log(2(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT))−2log(3)−log(3)−2log(2)}\begin{aligned}v_{T-3}(a_{T-3})&=\max_{a_{T-2}}\left\{log(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3}-a_{T-2})+1*v_{T-2}(a_{T-2})\right\}\\&=\max_{a_{T-2}}\left\{log(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3}-a_{T-2})+log(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)+2log(2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T))-2log(3)-log(3)-2log(2)\right\}\end{aligned}vT−3​(aT−3​)​=aT−2​max​{log(aT−3​+yT−3​−aT−2​)+1∗vT−2​(aT−2​)}=aT−2​max​{log(aT−3​+yT−3​−aT−2​)+log(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)+2log(2(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​))−2log(3)−log(3)−2log(2)}​

4.2 Take the FOC and solve for aT−2a_{T-2}aT−2​ to get optimal policy:
∂∂aT−2=1aT−3+yT−3−aT−2∗(−1)+1aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT+22(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT)∗2=062(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT)=1aT−3+yT−3−aT−26(aT−3+yT−3−aT−2)=2(aT−2+yT−2+yT−1+yT)6aT−3+6yT−3−6aT−2=2aT−2+2yT−2+2yT−1+2yT6(aT−3+yT−3)−2(yT−2+yT−1+yT)=8aT−234(aT−3+yT−3)−14(yT−2+yT−1+yT)=aT−2\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial a_{T-2}}=\frac{1}{a_{T-3}+y_{T-3}-a_{T-2}}*(-1)+\frac{1}{a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T}+\frac{2}{2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)}*2&=0\\\frac{6}{2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)}&=\frac{1}{a_{T-3}+y_{T-3}-a_{T-2}}\\6(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3}-a_{T-2})&=2(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)\\6a_{T-3}+6y_{T-3}-6a_{T-2}&=2a_{T-2}+2y_{T-2}+2y_{T-1}+2y_T\\6(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3})-2(y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)&=8a_{T-2}\\\frac{3}{4}(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3})-\frac{1}{4}(y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)&=a_{T-2}\end{aligned}∂aT−2​∂​=aT−3​+yT−3​−aT−2​1​∗(−1)+aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​1​+2(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)2​∗22(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)6​6(aT−3​+yT−3​−aT−2​)6aT−3​+6yT−3​−6aT−2​6(aT−3​+yT−3​)−2(yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)43​(aT−3​+yT−3​)−41​(yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)​=0=aT−3​+yT−3​−aT−2​1​=2(aT−2​+yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)=2aT−2​+2yT−2​+2yT−1​+2yT​=8aT−2​=aT−2​​

Optimal policy for aT−2(aT−3)a_{T-2}(a_{T-3})aT−2​(aT−3​): aT−2(aT−3)=34(aT−3+yT−3)−14(yT−2+yT−1+yT)a_{T-2}(a_{T-3})=\frac{3}{4}(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3})-\frac{1}{4}(y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)aT−2​(aT−3​)=43​(aT−3​+yT−3​)−41​(yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)

  1. We stop iterating at this point and try to generalize the result: note that I rewrite aT(aT−1)=aT−1+yT−1−yT2a_T(a_{T-1})=\frac{a_{T-1}+y_{T-1}-y_T}{2}aT​(aT−1​)=2aT−1​+yT−1​−yT​​ to match the pattern of the other equations.
    aT+1(aT)=0aT(aT−1)=12(aT−1+yT−1)−12(yT)aT−1(aT−2)=23(aT−2+yT−2)−13(yT−1+yT)aT−2(aT−3)=34(aT−3+yT−3)−14(yT−2+yT−1+yT)\begin{aligned}a_{T+1}(a_T)&=0\\[1.5em]a_T(a_{T-1})&=\frac{1}{2}(a_{T-1}+y_{T-1})-\frac{1}{2}(y_T)\\[1.5em]a_{T-1}(a_{T-2})&=\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2})-\frac{1}{3}(y_{T-1}+y_T)\\[1.5em]a_{T-2}(a_{T-3})&=\frac{3}{4}(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3})-\frac{1}{4}(y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)\\[1.5em]\end{aligned}aT+1​(aT​)aT​(aT−1​)aT−1​(aT−2​)aT−2​(aT−3​)​=0=21​(aT−1​+yT−1​)−21​(yT​)=32​(aT−2​+yT−2​)−31​(yT−1​+yT​)=43​(aT−3​+yT−3​)−41​(yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)​

First, look at the LHS.
att=0\text{at} \enspace t=0att=0 aT+1(aT),a_{T+1}(a_T),aT+1​(aT​), att=1\text{at} \enspace t=1att=1 aT(aT−1)⋮a_{T}(a_{T-1})\\\vdotsaT​(aT−1​)⋮
  ⟹  aT−t+1(aT−t)\implies a_{T-t+1}(a_{T-t})⟹aT−t+1​(aT−t​)

Next, look at the first term on RHS. att=2\text{at} \enspace t=2 \enspaceatt=2 23(aT−2+yT−2),\frac{2}{3}(a_{T-2}+y_{T-2}),32​(aT−2​+yT−2​), att=3\text{at} \enspace t=3att=3 34(aT−3+yT−3)⋮\frac{3}{4}(a_{T-3}+y_{T-3})\\\vdots43​(aT−3​+yT−3​)⋮   ⟹  tt+1(aT−t+yT−t)\implies \frac{t}{t+1}(a_{T-t}+y_{T-t})⟹t+1t​(aT−t​+yT−t​)

(this one was easy)

Lastly, the second term on the RHS. att=2\text{at} \enspace t=2 \enspaceatt=2 13(yT−1+yT),\frac{1}{3}(y_{T-1}+y_T),31​(yT−1​+yT​), att=3\text{at} \enspace t=3att=3 14(yT−2+yT−1+yT)⋮\frac{1}{4}(y_{T-2}+y_{T-1}+y_T)\\\vdots41​(yT−2​+yT−1​+yT​)⋮ This looks like a sequence. This calls for a summator. Note that at period 3, we have subscripts on yyy up to t−2t-2t−2, at period 2 we have subscripts up to T−1T-1T−1, etc… Thus, we need to introduce a shift. This is done by adjusting the upper limit of the summation (stopping point) by one period, to t−1t-1t−1. To not get confused, we call the index of the summation “iii”. Then we get:   ⟹  1t+1∑i=0t−1yT−i\implies \frac{1}{t+1}\sum^{t-1}_{i=0}y_{T-i}⟹t+11​i=0∑t−1​yT−i​

In conclusion, the policy function for each period is: aT−t+1(aT−t)=tt+1(aT−t+yT−t)−1t+1∑i=0t−1yT−ia_{T-t+1}(a_{T-t})=\frac{t}{t+1}(a_{T-t}+y_{T-t})-\frac{1}{t+1}\sum^{t-1}_{i=0}y_{T-i}aT−t+1​(aT−t​)=t+1t​(aT−t​+yT−t​)−t+11​i=0∑t−1​yT−i​

Note that since β=1\beta=1β=1, the agent is perfectly indifferent between consumption now vs. in the future. This implies that the agent has an incentive to smooth consumption.

Since ttt refers to a specific period, let’s plug in a general T−1T-1T−1 for ttt in our optimal policy function:
aT−(T−1)+1(aT−(T−1))=T−1T−1+1(aT−(T−1)+yT−(T−1))−1T−1+1∑i=0(T−1)−1yT−ia_{T-(T-1)+1}(a_{T-(T-1)})=\frac{T-1}{T-1+1}(a_{T-(T-1)}+y_{T-(T-1)})-\frac{1}{T-1+1}\sum^{(T-1)-1}_{i=0}y_{T-i}aT−(T−1)+1​(aT−(T−1)​)=T−1+1T−1​(aT−(T−1)​+yT−(T−1)​)−T−1+11​i=0∑(T−1)−1​yT−i​

a2(a1)=T−1T(a1+y1)−1T∑i=0T−2yT−ia_{2}(a_{1})=\frac{T-1}{T}(a_{1}+y_{1})-\frac{1}{T}\sum^{T-2}_{i=0}y_{T-i}a2​(a1​)=TT−1​(a1​+y1​)−T1​i=0∑T−2​yT−i​

Or writing out the summator (we can include period RRR here because that’s the period until when the agent works, hence receives income yyy):
a2(a1)=T−1T(a1+y1)−1T(yT−0+yT−1+...+yT−(T−2))=T−1T(a1+y1)−1T(yR+yR−1+...+y2)\begin{aligned}a_{2}(a_{1})&=\frac{T-1}{T}(a_{1}+y_{1})-\frac{1}{T}(y_{T-0}+y_{T-1}+...+y_{T-(T-2)})\\&=\frac{T-1}{T}(a_{1}+y_{1})-\frac{1}{T}(y_{R}+y_{R-1}+...+y_2)\end{aligned}a2​(a1​)​=TT−1​(a1​+y1​)−T1​(yT−0​+yT−1​+...+yT−(T−2)​)=TT−1​(a1​+y1​)−T1​(yR​+yR−1​+...+y2​)​

We have a general equation telling us what the decision on wealth of the agent in period t=2t=2t=2, a2a_2a2​ is, given his wealth of the previous period, a1a_1a1​. This equation holds for every period. Below an explanation:

  • First term on RHS: T−1T\frac{T-1}{T}TT−1​ of period one wealth and income (a1+y1)a_1+y_1)a1​+y1​) is saved, while 1−T−1T=1T1-\frac{T-1}{T}=\frac{1}{T}1−TT−1​=T1​ of period one wealth and income are consumed
  • from this, the second term on the RHS is subtracted. This term represents the share, 1T\frac{1}{T}T1​ of his current (y2y_2y2​) and future (y3y_3y3​ until his last work period yRy_RyR​) income streams that the agent consumes. This implies that he in turn saves 1−1T=T−1T1-\frac{1}{T}=\frac{T-1}{T}1−T1​=TT−1​ of his future income streams.

We can also see that this is true by plugging a2(a1)a_2(a_1)a2​(a1​) into the budget constraint and solve for c1c_1c1​:

ct=at+yt−at+11+r=a1+y1−a21+0=a1+y1−(T−1T(a1+y1)−1T∑i=0T−2yT−i)=1T(a1+yy)+1T∑i=0T−2yT−ic1=1T(a1+y1+y2+...+yR−1+yR)\begin{aligned}c_t&=a_t+y_t-\frac{a_{t+1}}{1+r}\\&=a_1+y_1-\frac{a_{2}}{1+0}\\&=a_1+y_1-\left(\frac{T-1}{T}(a_{1}+y_{1})-\frac{1}{T}\sum^{T-2}_{i=0}y_{T-i}\right)\\&=\frac{1}{T}(a_1+y_y)+\frac{1}{T}\sum^{T-2}_{i=0}y_{T-i}\\c_1&=\frac{1}{T}\left(a_1+y_1+y_2+...+y_{R-1}+y_R\right)\end{aligned}ct​c1​​=at​+yt​−1+rat+1​​=a1​+y1​−1+0a2​​=a1​+y1​−(TT−1​(a1​+y1​)−T1​i=0∑T−2​yT−i​)=T1​(a1​+yy​)+T1​i=0∑T−2​yT−i​=T1​(a1​+y1​+y2​+...+yR−1​+yR​)​

This shows us clearly, that the agent consumes fraction 1T\frac{1}{T}T1​ of his current wealth and current and future lifetime income.

By implication, he saves fraction T−1T\frac{T-1}{T}TT−1​ each period.

Since 1T\frac{1}{T}T1​ is a constant, a constant fraction is consumed per period, which is perfect consumption smoothing.

Note: if this fraction wouldn’t be constant but instead a varying term, we would call it imperfect consumption smoothing.

Q2: Dynamic Programming

A consumer’s problem (so-called cake-eating problem):{max{ct}t=0∞∑t=0∞βlog(ct)s.t.at+1=(1+r)(at−ct),a0 given\left\{\begin{array}{lll} max_{\left\{c_t\right\}^\infty_{t=0}}\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta log(c_t)\\\text{s.t.}\\ a_{t+1}=(1+r)(a_t-c_t), \qquad a_0 \enspace \text{ given}\end{array} \right.⎩⎨⎧​max{ct​}t=0∞​​∑t=0∞​βlog(ct​)s.t.at+1​=(1+r)(at​−ct​),a0​ given​ with 0<β≤1,0<\beta\le1,\enspace0<β≤1, r>0r>0r>0.

  1. What is (are) the state variable(s)?

Solution:

State variables are the ones that are known at the decision time, cannot be changed at that time and have an influence on your decision. The state variables in Q2 are: ata_tat​

  1. What is (are) the control variable(s)?

Solution:

Control variables are the ones that are optimally chosen. The control variables in Q2 are: at+1,cta_{t+1}, \enspace c_tat+1​,ct​

  1. State the Bellman equation for this problem.

Solution:

For the main function, solve the constraint for ctc_tct​ and plug it in:
at+1=(1+r)(at−ct)at+1=(1+r)at−(1+r)ct(1+r)ct=(1+r)at−at+1ct=at−at+11+r\begin{aligned}a_{t+1}&=(1+r)(a_t-c_t)\\a_{t+1}&=(1+r)a_t-(1+r)c_t\\(1+r)c_t&=(1+r)a_t-a_{t+1}\\c_t&=a_t-\frac{a_{t+1}}{1+r}\end{aligned}at+1​at+1​(1+r)ct​ct​​=(1+r)(at​−ct​)=(1+r)at​−(1+r)ct​=(1+r)at​−at+1​=at​−1+rat+1​​​

Since we have an infinite-horizon problem, we don’t use time subscripts! Use ’ to indicate future period. The Bellman equation reads:

v(at)=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βvt+1(a′)}v(a_t)=\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v_{t+1}(a')\right\}v(at​)=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βvt+1​(a′)}

  1. Find the optimal policy rule based on the following methods:
    a) Guess and verify. A good guess will be v(a)=A+Blog⁡(a)v(a)=A+B\log(a)v(a)=A+Blog(a) for some constants AAA and BBB.
    b) Value function iteration
    c) Policy function iteration (Howard’s improvement algorithm)

Solution a) Guess and verify:

as suggested in the exercise, guess v(a)=A+Blog⁡(a)v(a)=A+B\log(a)v(a)=A+Blog(a) for some constants AAA and BBB. Don’t forget the ’ at the a, because our control variable is a′a'a′!

  1. Plug this in. The Bellman equation then becomes:

v(a)=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+β[A+Blog⁡(a′)]}v(a)=\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta [A+B\log(a')]\right\}v(a)=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+β[A+Blog(a′)]}

  1. Take the FOC and get optimal policy:
    ∂∂a′=1a−(1+r)−1a′(−11+r)+βB1a′=0βB1a′=1a−(1+r)−1a′11+r(a−(1+r)−1a′)βB1a′=11+raβB1a′−a′βBa′(1+r)=11+raβB1a′−βB1+r=11+raβB1a′=1+βB1+ra′aβB=1+r1+βBthe optimal policy is:a′=1+r1+βBaβB\begin{aligned}\frac{\partial}{\partial a'}=\frac{1}{a-(1+r)^{-1}a'}\left(-\frac{1}{1+r}\right)+\beta B\frac{1}{a'}&=0\\[1em]\beta B\frac{1}{a'}&=\frac{1}{a-(1+r)^{-1}a'}\frac{1}{1+r}\\[1em](a-(1+r)^{-1}a')\beta B\frac{1}{a'}&=\frac{1}{1+r}\\a\beta B\frac{1}{a'}-\frac{a'\beta B}{a'(1+r)}&=\frac{1}{1+r}\\a\beta B\frac{1}{a'}-\frac{\beta B}{1+r}&=\frac{1}{1+r}\\a\beta B\frac{1}{a'}&=\frac{1+\beta B}{1+r}\\\frac{a'}{a\beta B}&=\frac{1+r}{1+\beta B}\\[1em]\text{the optimal policy is:}\\a'&=\frac{1+r}{1+\beta B}a\beta B\end{aligned}∂a′∂​=a−(1+r)−1a′1​(−1+r1​)+βBa′1​βBa′1​(a−(1+r)−1a′)βBa′1​aβBa′1​−a′(1+r)a′βB​aβBa′1​−1+rβB​aβBa′1​aβBa′​the optimal policy is:a′​=0=a−(1+r)−1a′1​1+r1​=1+r1​=1+r1​=1+r1​=1+r1+βB​=1+βB1+r​=1+βB1+r​aβB​

  2. Plug this optimal policy back into our value function, and “bring it” into the functional form we want:

v(a)=log⁡(a−1+r1+βBaβB1+r)+β[A+Blog⁡(1+r1+βBaβB)]=log⁡(a−aβB1+βB)+βA+βB[log⁡((1+r)βB1+βB)+log⁡(a)]try to get it into the functional form A+Blog(a)=log⁡(a(1+βB)1+βB−aβB1+βB)+βA+βBlog⁡((1+r)βB1+βB)+βBlog⁡(a)=log⁡(a+aβB−aβB1+βB)+"=log⁡(a1+βB)+"=log⁡(a)−log⁡(1+βB)+βA+βBlog⁡((1+r)βB1+βB)+βBlog⁡(a)=−log⁡(1+βB)+βA+βBlog⁡((1+r)βB1+βB)⏟assume this is A+(1+βB)⏟assume this is Blog⁡(a)so we have our form:=A+Blog⁡(a)\begin{aligned}v(a)&=\log\left(a- \frac{\frac{1+r}{1+\beta B}a\beta B}{1+r}\right)+\beta \left[A+B\log\left(\frac{1+r}{1+\beta B}a\beta B\right)\right]\\&=\log\left(a-\frac{a\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)+\beta A+\beta B\left[\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)+\log(a)\right]\\\\\text{try to get it into the functional form A+Blog(a)}\\&=\log\left(\frac{a(1+\beta B)}{1+\beta B}-\frac{a\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)+\beta A+\beta B\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)+\beta B\log(a)\\&=\log\left(\frac{a+a\beta B-a\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)+\qquad "\\&=\log\left(\frac{a}{1+\beta B}\right)\qquad\enspace\enspace\enspace+\qquad "\\&=\log(a)-\log(1+\beta B)+\beta A+\beta B\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)+\beta B\log(a)\\&=\underbrace{-\log(1+\beta B)+\beta A+\beta B\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)}_{\text{assume this is }A}+\underbrace{(1+\beta B)}_{\text{assume this is }B}\log(a)\end{aligned}\\\text{so we have our form:}\\[1em]=A+B\log(a)v(a)try to get it into the functional form A+Blog(a)​=log(a−1+r1+βB1+r​aβB​)+β[A+Blog(1+βB1+r​aβB)]=log(a−1+βBaβB​)+βA+βB[log(1+βB(1+r)βB​)+log(a)]=log(1+βBa(1+βB)​−1+βBaβB​)+βA+βBlog(1+βB(1+r)βB​)+βBlog(a)=log(1+βBa+aβB−aβB​)+"=log(1+βBa​)+"=log(a)−log(1+βB)+βA+βBlog(1+βB(1+r)βB​)+βBlog(a)=assume this is A−log(1+βB)+βA+βBlog(1+βB(1+r)βB​)​​+assume this is B(1+βB)​​log(a)​so we have our form:=A+Blog(a)

  1. Equate our functional form parts with AAA and BBB and solve for AAA and BBB (if functional form is incorrect, we won’t be able to solve here for parameters!):

BBB:B=(1+βB)B−βB=1B=11−β\begin{aligned}B&=(1+\beta B)\\B-\beta B&=1\\B&=\frac{1}{1-\beta}\end{aligned}BB−βBB​=(1+βB)=1=1−β1​​

AAA:A=−log⁡(1+βB)+βA+βBlog⁡((1+r)βB1+βB)=−log⁡(1+β11−β)+βA+β11−βlog⁡((1+r)β11−β1+β11−β)A−βA=−log⁡(1−β+β1−β)+β1−βlog⁡((1+r)β(1+β1−β)(1−β))(1−β)A=−log⁡(1)+log⁡(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡((1+r)β1−β+β1−β−ββ1−β)=log⁡(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡((1+r)β1−β+(1−β)β1−β)="+β1−βlog⁡((1+r)β1−β+β)(1−β)A=log⁡(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡[(1+r)β]A=11−β[log(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡[(1+r)β)]]\begin{aligned}A&=-\log(1+\beta B)+\beta A+\beta B\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta B}{1+\beta B}\right)\\&=-\log(1+\beta \frac{1}{1-\beta})+\beta A+\beta \frac{1}{1-\beta}\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta \frac{1}{1-\beta}}{1+\beta \frac{1}{1-\beta}}\right)\\A-\beta A&=-\log\left(\frac{1-\beta+\beta}{1-\beta}\right)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta}{(1+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta})(1-\beta)}\right)\\(1-\beta)A&=-\log(1)+\log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta}{1-\beta+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}-\beta\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}}\right)\\&=\log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta}{1-\beta+(1-\beta)\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}}\right)=\qquad"\enspace+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log\left(\frac{(1+r)\beta}{1-\beta+\beta}\right)\\(1-\beta)A&=\log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log[(1+r)\beta]\\A&=\frac{1}{1-\beta}\left[log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log[(1+r)\beta)]\right]\end{aligned}AA−βA(1−β)A(1−β)AA​=−log(1+βB)+βA+βBlog(1+βB(1+r)βB​)=−log(1+β1−β1​)+βA+β1−β1​log(1+β1−β1​(1+r)β1−β1​​)=−log(1−β1−β+β​)+1−ββ​log((1+1−ββ​)(1−β)(1+r)β​)=−log(1)+log(1−β)+1−ββ​log(1−β+1−ββ​−β1−ββ​(1+r)β​)=log(1−β)+1−ββ​log(1−β+(1−β)1−ββ​(1+r)β​)="+1−ββ​log(1−β+β(1+r)β​)=log(1−β)+1−ββ​log[(1+r)β]=1−β1​[log(1−β)+1−ββ​log[(1+r)β)]]​

  1. Get optimal policy by plugging BBB into the optimal policy function:

a′=1+r1+βBaβB=1+r1+β11−βaβ11−β=(1+r)aβ(1+β11−β)(1−β)=(1+r)aβ1−β+β1−β−ββ1−β=(1+r)aβ1−β+(1−β)β1−β=(1+r)aβ1−β+βa′=(1+r)aβ\begin{aligned}a'&=\frac{1+r}{1+\beta B}a\beta B\\&=\frac{1+r}{1+\beta\frac{1}{1-\beta}}a\beta\frac{1}{1-\beta}\\&=\frac{(1+r)a\beta}{(1+\beta\frac{1}{1-\beta})(1-\beta)}=\frac{(1+r)a\beta}{1-\beta+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}-\beta\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}}=\frac{(1+r)a\beta}{1-\beta+(1-\beta)\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}}=\frac{(1+r)a\beta}{1-\beta+\beta}\\a'&=(1+r)a\beta\end{aligned}a′a′​=1+βB1+r​aβB=1+β1−β1​1+r​aβ1−β1​=(1+β1−β1​)(1−β)(1+r)aβ​=1−β+1−ββ​−β1−ββ​(1+r)aβ​=1−β+(1−β)1−ββ​(1+r)aβ​=1−β+β(1+r)aβ​=(1+r)aβ​

  1. Plug optimal policy back into the value function to verify whether we got the right functional form.

v(a)=log⁡(a−(1+r)aβ)+β[A+Blog⁡((1+r)aβ)]=log⁡(a−(1+r)aβ)+β[(11−β[log(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡[(1+r)β)]])+11−βlog⁡((1+r)aβ)]=log⁡(a−(1+r)aβ)+β1−βlog⁡(1−β)+β2(1−β)2log⁡((1+r)β)+β1−βlog⁡((1+r)aβ)\begin{aligned}v(a)&=\log\left(a- (1+r)a\beta\right)+\beta \left[A+B\log\left((1+r)a\beta\right)\right]\\&=\log\left(a- (1+r)a\beta\right)+\beta \left[\left(\frac{1}{1-\beta}\left[log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log[(1+r)\beta)]\right]\right)+\frac{1}{1-\beta}\log\left((1+r)a\beta\right)\right]\\&=\log(a-(1+r)a\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta^2}{(1-\beta)^2}\log((1+r)\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log((1+r)a\beta)\end{aligned}v(a)​=log(a−(1+r)aβ)+β[A+Blog((1+r)aβ)]=log(a−(1+r)aβ)+β[(1−β1​[log(1−β)+1−ββ​log[(1+r)β)]])+1−β1​log((1+r)aβ)]=log(a−(1+r)aβ)+1−ββ​log(1−β)+(1−β)2β2​log((1+r)β)+1−ββ​log((1+r)aβ)​

Solution b) Value function iteration:

Initial guess: v0(a)=0v_0(a)=0v0​(a)=0

Solve one-period problem: v1(a)=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+β∗0}v_1(a)=\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta*0\right\}v1​(a)=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+β∗0}
Solution (function is maximized when) a′=0a'=0a′=0.

Hence, v1(a)=log⁡(a−0)=log⁡(a)v_1(a)=\log(a-0)=\log(a)v1​(a)=log(a−0)=log(a)

Plug this into the Bellman equation: v2(a)=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+β∗log⁡(a′)}v_2(a)=\max_{a'}\left\{\log(a-\frac{a'}{1+r})+\beta*\log(a')\right\}v2​(a)=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+β∗log(a′)}

Note that you add a prime to the aaa!!

Take FOC and get solution:

Solution c) Policy function iteration:

Note: unlike with G&V and VFI, we use the sequential form (sum) here because we want to stick with this policy function over all time periods (infinitely)

Now note that ∑t=0∞tβt=β(1−β)2\sum^\infty_{t=0}t\beta^t=\frac{\beta}{(1-\beta)^2}∑t=0∞​tβt=(1−β)2β​. For a derivation of this see my notes below: Thus we have that:
v(a0)=11−β[log⁡(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡[β(1+r)]+log⁡(a0)]Plug this into the Bellman equation:max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+β∗[11−β[log⁡(1−β)+β1−βlog⁡[β(1+r)]+log⁡(a′)]]}Take the FOC:−11+r1a−a′1+r+β∗11−β1a′=0β(1−β)a′=11+r1a−a′1+rβ[(1+r)(a−a′1+r)]=(1−β)a′β(1+r)a−β(1+r)a′1+r=(1−β)a′β(1+r)a=(1−β)a′+βa′=a′−βa′+βa′=a′\begin{aligned}v(a_0)&=\frac{1}{1-\beta}[\log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log[\beta(1+r)]+\log(a_0)]\\[1em]&\text{Plug this into the Bellman equation:}\\[1em]&\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta*\left[\frac{1}{1-\beta}[\log(1-\beta)+\frac{\beta}{1-\beta}\log[\beta(1+r)]+\log(a')]\right]\right\}\\[1em]&\text{Take the FOC:}\\[1em]&-\frac{1}{1+r}\frac{1}{a-\frac{a'}{1+r}}+\beta*\frac{1}{1-\beta}\frac{1}{a'}=0\\[1em]\frac{\beta}{(1-\beta)a'}&=\frac{1}{1+r}\frac{1}{a-\frac{a'}{1+r}}\\[1em]\beta[(1+r)(a-\frac{a'}{1+r})]&=(1-\beta)a'\\\beta(1+r)a-\beta(1+r)\frac{a'}{1+r}&=(1-\beta)a'\\\beta(1+r)a&=(1-\beta)a'+\beta a'=a'-\beta a'+\beta a'=a'\end{aligned}v(a0​)(1−β)a′β​β[(1+r)(a−1+ra′​)]β(1+r)a−β(1+r)1+ra′​β(1+r)a​=1−β1​[log(1−β)+1−ββ​log[β(1+r)]+log(a0​)]Plug this into the Bellman equation:a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+β∗[1−β1​[log(1−β)+1−ββ​log[β(1+r)]+log(a′)]]}Take the FOC:−1+r1​a−1+ra′​1​+β∗1−β1​a′1​=0=1+r1​a−1+ra′​1​=(1−β)a′=(1−β)a′=(1−β)a′+βa′=a′−βa′+βa′=a′​

  1. Show that this system has a unique solution.

Solution:

To verify that the system is a contraction mapping we can apply Blackwell’s Theorem:

Theorem: (Blackwell’s sufficient conditions for a contraction). Let X∈RiX\in\mathbb{R}^iX∈Ri, and let B(X)B(X)B(X) be a space of bounded functions f:X→Rf:X\to\mathbb{R}f:X→R, with the sup norm. Let T:B(X)→B(X)T:B(X)\to B(X)T:B(X)→B(X) be an operator satisfying

a) monotonicity f,g∈B(X)f, g\in B(X)f,g∈B(X) (the space of bounded functions), and f(x)≤g(x)f(x)\le g(x)f(x)≤g(x), for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, implies (Tf)(x)≤(Tg)(x)(Tf)(x)\le (Tg)(x)(Tf)(x)≤(Tg)(x), for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X;

b) discounting there exists some β∈(0,1)\beta \in (0,1)β∈(0,1) such that [T(f+a)](x)≤(Tf)(x)+βaall f∈B(X),a≥0,x∈X[T(f+a)](x)\le (Tf)(x)+\beta a\qquad \text{all } f\in B(X), a\ge 0, x\in X[T(f+a)](x)≤(Tf)(x)+βaall f∈B(X),a≥0,x∈X

Then TTT is a contraction with modulus β\betaβ

Note: Here, (f+a)(x)(f+a)(x)(f+a)(x) is the function defined by (f+a)(x)=f(x)+a(f+a)(x)=f(x)+a(f+a)(x)=f(x)+a

Proof: see note below:

Define an operator T:B→BT:B\to BT:B→B.

We want to check Blackwell’s theorem for the following Bellman operator:

(Tv)(a)=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)}(Tv)(a)=\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\right\}(Tv)(a)=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)} with discount factor β\betaβ.

Assume v,v^v, \hat{v}v,v^ with v(a)≤v^(a)v(a)\le \hat{v}(a)v(a)≤v^(a) always holds.

a) Then monotonicity:

log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)≤log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv^(a′)\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\le\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta \hat{v}(a')log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)≤log(a−1+ra′​)+βv^(a′)
also must hold.

Proof: rearrange inequality

βv(a′)≤βv^(a′)v(a′)≤v^(a′)\beta v(a')\le \beta \hat{v}(a')\\v(a')\le\hat{v}(a')βv(a′)≤βv^(a′)v(a′)≤v^(a′)

Then it must also hold that (Tv)(a)≤(Tv^)(a)(Tv)(a)\le (T\hat{v})(a)(Tv)(a)≤(Tv^)(a) for all aaa.

b) discounting:

∃β∈(0,1)\exists \beta \in (0,1)∃β∈(0,1) such that [T(v+z)](a)≤(Tv)(a)+βz[T(v+z)](a)\le (Tv)(a)+\beta z\\ [T(v+z)](a)≤(Tv)(a)+βz

Proof: [T(v+z)](a)=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)+βz}[T(v+z)](a)=\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')+\beta z\right\}[T(v+z)](a)=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)+βz}

Then: max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)+βz}≤max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)}+βz\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')+\beta z\right\}\le \max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\right\}+\beta za′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)+βz}≤a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)}+βz

Since βz\beta zβz is a constant, we can take it out of the maximization: max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)}+βz=max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)}+βzmax⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)}+βz≤max⁡a′{log⁡(a−a′1+r)+βv(a′)}+βz\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\right\}+\beta z= \max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\right\}+\beta z\\\max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\right\}+\beta z\le \max_{a'}\left\{\log\left(a-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)+\beta v(a')\right\}+\beta za′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)}+βz=a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)}+βza′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)}+βz≤a′max​{log(a−1+ra′​)+βv(a′)}+βz

Which ends the proof.

Q3: Stochastic Savings Problem

An agent solves the following problem: {max{ct}t=0∞E0∑t=0∞βct1−σ1−σs.t.at+1=(1+r)(at+yt−ct)at+1≥0,a0 given\left\{\begin{array}{lll} max_{\left\{c_t\right\}^\infty_{t=0}}\mathbb{E}_0\sum^\infty_{t=0}\beta \frac{c_t^{1-\sigma}}{1-\sigma}\\\text{s.t.}\\ a_{t+1}=(1+r)(a_t+y_t-c_t) \qquad a_{t+1}\ge0, \enspace a_0 \text{ given}\end{array} \right.⎩⎨⎧​max{ct​}t=0∞​​E0​∑t=0∞​β1−σct1−σ​​s.t.at+1​=(1+r)(at​+yt​−ct​)at+1​≥0,a0​ given​ where ctc_tct​ represents consumption, β\betaβ is the discount rate, and yty_tyt​ denotes the stochastic income for each period. The income yty_tyt​ may take one of the two values yt∈{yL,yH}y_t\in \left\{y_L, y_H\right\}yt​∈{yL​,yH​} and follows the 2-state Markov-Process defined in class: [πLLπLHπHLπHH]\begin{bmatrix}\pi_{LL}&\pi_{LH}\\\pi_{HL}&\pi_{HH}\end{bmatrix}[πLL​πHL​​πLH​πHH​​]

  1. What is (are) the state variable(s)?

Solution:

State variables are the ones that are known at the decision time, cannot be changed at that time and have an influence on your decision. The state variables in Q3 are: yt,aty_t, a_tyt​,at​

  1. What is (are) the control variable(s)?

Solution:

Control variables are the ones that are optimally chosen. The control variables in Q3 are: at+1a_{t+1}at+1​

  1. State this agent’s Bellman equation.

Solution: at+1=(1+r)(at+yt−ct)(1+r)ct=(1+r)(at+yt)−at+1ct=at+yt−at+11+r\begin{aligned}a_{t+1}&=(1+r)(a_t+y_t-c_t)\\(1+r)c_t&=(1+r)(a_t+y_t)-a_{t+1}\\c_t&=a_t+y_t-\frac{a_{t+1}}{1+r}\end{aligned}at+1​(1+r)ct​ct​​=(1+r)(at​+yt​−ct​)=(1+r)(at​+yt​)−at+1​=at​+yt​−1+rat+1​​​

v(a,y)=max⁡a′≥0{(a+y−a′1+r)1−σ1−σ+Eβ[v(a′,y′)∣y]}v(a,y)=\max_{a'\ge0}\left\{\frac{\left(a+y-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)^{1-\sigma}}{1-\sigma}+\mathbb{E}\beta [v(a',y')|y]\right\}v(a,y)=a′≥0max​⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​1−σ(a+y−1+ra′​)1−σ​+Eβ[v(a′,y′)∣y]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​

  • Note that when the problem states something like at+1≥0a_{t+1}\ge0at+1​≥0, then you gotta write this below the maximization!
  • Note the expectation operator on the beta but not on the objective function
  • Note the primes on the value function v(a′,y′)v(a',y')v(a′,y′)
  1. Suppose πLL=πLH=πHL=πHH=0.5\pi_{LL}=\pi_{LH}=\pi_{HL}=\pi_{HH}=0.5πLL​=πLH​=πHL​=πHH​=0.5, i.e. when yty_tyt​ is i.i.d. In this case we can define “cash-in-hand” in the beginning of the period as wt=at+ytw_t=a_t+y_twt​=at​+yt​ and the state variables can be summarized to this single variable. Write down the Bellman equation in which wtw_twt​ is the only state variable. Briefly explain the practical benefit of this transformation.

Solution: v(w)=max⁡a′≥0{(w−a′1+r)1−σ1−σ+Eβ[v(w′)∣y]}s.t. w′=a′+y′v(w)=\max_{a'\ge0}\left\{\frac{\left(w-\frac{a'}{1+r}\right)^{1-\sigma}}{1-\sigma}+\mathbb{E}\beta [v(w')|y]\right\}\\\text{s.t. }w'=a'+y'v(w)=a′≥0max​⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​1−σ(w−1+ra′​)1−σ​+Eβ[v(w′)∣y]⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​s.t. w′=a′+y′

This transformation reduces the state space, which weakens the curse of dimensionality!
